title: Really helpful app
review: Thank you for this app. I’m smart phone addicted person. And it’s hard for me to learn my online classes. This app helps to not touch my phone

title: Pomodoro or 25 minute focus not prioritized
review:
app could be a lot better!

i was tricked into buying, i thought it was pomodoro centric but it's not. the pomodoro time limit gives you weak trees in the app. 

the art and animation [the lack thereof] could be much better. maybe even ambient sound options. it's such a disappointment when an app should be much better but isn't. 

they should make it so that you get a whole tree by 25 minutes; and after four trees, on the fifth numbered tree, your daily forest should get some kind of bonus. additionally, the fifth tree should be older.
developerResponse: {'id': 11677510, 'body': 'Hello, \nWe are really sorry to know that you do not enjoy Forest. title: Helpful for a distracted mind

title: Great studying app
review: I love this app, it is easy to use and it helps me focus on my studying. I love how you can collect points and  grow a forest if you want. 10/10 super recommended!!!

title: Brilliant!
review: So far this has been the most effective tool I’ve found for managing my time!  Love it, I’m trying to get other people using it too.

title: Helps me study

title: Privacy Violations
review: Nope.  This app won’t let you use family sharing unless you send the company a copy of your driver’s license and social security card (or similar).   They hilariously claim they will delete afterward but I trust some random company like this exactly zero.  This app is useless if I have to have my privacy violated in order to benefit from it.  No thanks.  Got a refund and I’ll be moving along.
developerResponse:
{'id': 11670529, 'body': 'Hello,
The family sharing option is operated by Apple. As developers, we do not have the permission to make any adjustments on this matter, and thus we are unable to check on how your family sharing feature is running.
We recommend that you contact Apple for further assistance as we have no control over this whatsoever. Thank you for understanding.
- Forest', 'modified': '2019-11-05T15:33:22Z'}

developerResponse: {'id': 22046684, 'body': "Hi, thank you for the feedback. You don't actually have to pay money for the trees, you can earn the coins by focusing more. The main purpose of this app is to help users stay focused on their tasks and the coin mechanism is there to motivate users to stay focused more and unlock the trees that they like. Pretty trees are worth the effort. :)", 'modified': '2021-04-05T09:27:28Z'}

title: Fun way to stay focused and help a good cause
review:
This is a fun little app and the integration with a real tree planting program is pretty motivating. 

It’s pretty strict with no way to pause or make app exceptions. I like that but some might dislike it. 

I kind of wish there were more natural  trees (oak, maple, birch, etc) as most of them are kind of silly (treehouse, Christmas tree, triple tree) but that’s a really minor complaint. 

It’s a good app and worth the money.

developerResponse: {'id': 4365211, 'body': 'Hi,\nSince the cost of planting real trees is covered by the company, complications can arise when users plant too many real trees; the cost can easily exceed the app’s revenue.  Therefore, the amount of real trees users can plant will be limited.  However, we will consider if there is a way for our user to plant more trees in the future.\nThank you for the feedback and feel free to contact us via our in-app feedback system if you have further questions or suggestions. - Forest', 'modified': '2019-04-18T15:17:14Z'}

review: Just paid my $2 only to find out that the app is basically useless. There is no way to turn on “deep focus mode” (which stops you from using other apps and is what makes the concept work). Toggle button isn’t greyed out but it doesn’t toggle. Save your money.

title: Motivates me
review:
PROS

- store price increases each time you buy something so it motivates you to study more to get the tree/bush that you want
- let’s you label the task for the session
- there’s a daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly tracker 

CONS

- it tries to integrate having friends in a study session, but it’s a hassle to do so because you have to restart the session by opening up a new session. (You can’t renew the session)

for developer(s):
i recommend making it possible to combine two plants together. for example, if you added two bushes together and your accumulated time off your phone would equal more than 25 minuets, you can get a tree.
as someone who uses this app and often miscalculates how much i can be off my phone and studying, it would be less of an inconvenience (if anything, it’s a tad bit frustrating [as my forest could seem more impressive]). 

thank you !! :))

developerResponse:
{'id': 4530586, 'body': 'Hello,

Due to the limitation of the iOS system, we cannot determine what app the user is currently using. Therefore we cannot implement the whitelist feature for the iOS version. As a workaround, we built a ""Work with Phone"" feature, which can be enabled in the settings page. This feature enables users to use work related apps during their planting periods, but users will have to be honest with themselves when using this feature. 

The trees planted with this feature enabled will not be counted towards the leaderboard, and users will only receive half the reward if they exit Forest during the planting period. 

Currently, the whitelist feature cannot be implemented for iOS. If you see features similar to whitelist on other apps, please let us know so that we may figure out how it was implemented. 

Thank you for your suggestion. :) - Forest', 'modified': '2018-08-06T03:51:44Z'}

developerResponse: {'id': 2858519, 'body': 'Hello, you can choose to log in with your Facebook app on your phone or by entering your Facebook username and password. If the Facebook app on your phone is connected to your current Facebook account, you can choose the "log in with Facebook app" option. The other way is to simply enter your username and password. We hope this helps! Forest', 'modified': '2018-03-19T03:01:09Z'}

title: Great app. Coin adjustment needed
review:
Great Pomodoro app. It’s a good touch to allow extended time not go wasted after a full Pomodoro is over, if one chooses to record it. 
Most trees begin at 500 coins. It doesn’t make sense to have 9-12 coins earned per Pomodoro. This makes accumulating 500 coins unreasonable
developerResponse: {'id': 9670712, 'body': 'Hi, we understand your point, but if coins were big and easy to get, plants and sounds that require coins to unlock would all be easily obtained, which might cause users to lose motivation soon. Thus, it takes time and efforts to accumulate coins. They can be earned by planting trees or unlocking achievements. We hope you understand. :) - Forest', 'modified': '2019-07-15T16:25:38Z'}

developerResponse: {'id': 18829261, 'body': "Hello,\nSince the cost of planting real trees is covered by the company, complications might arise when users plant too many real trees; the cost can also easily exceed the app's revenue. Therefore, the number of real trees that each user can plant is limited. We hope you understand and we will keep looking for other possibilities.\n- Forest", 'modified': '2020-11-01T15:04:28Z'}

title: Like it on IPhone
review: But why in this time and age can’t there be an Apple Watch app that is similar to the iPhone one? We are on the Apple Watch 6 now and still nothing? I bought the app and was very very happy with it until I tried to use it on my watch. Useless without it. 👎🏼
developerResponse:
{'id': 17977031, 'body': 'Hi,
If the planting progress isn't shown on your Apple Watch, please tap on "Complication" on the watch, then refresh the page, and the progress should show up.
Currently you cannot start a planting session from your watch because we cannot sync the planting progress on phones and watches simultaneously, meaning that users could still use their phones if they started planting on their watch.
We will continue to work on syncing these plant sessions nevertheless. Thank you for the feedback! :)', 'modified': '2020-09-20T13:54:23Z'}

-You can still answer messages when your screen is locked

Cons:
-It's easy to forget about the app and not use it for a while
All in all a great resource, especially for students

title: One of the best apps I’ve ever purchased
review:
Here’s the truth: I’m only in middle school but this app has been a LIFESAVER. I’m a straight A student but still find myself procrastinating and not putting all my attention toward my schoolwork. Especially when I have an exam, I always wait till the last minute to study. Ever since getting this app though, I have found myself being more productive. This app allows me to set a goal for myself for when I would like to get something done in a period of time but still allows be to do it correctly. It makes you want to get your work done because you are building a forest while spending time towards your responsibilities. I have stopped looking at my phone every five seconds and have learned to detach from social media. This app has helped me pick up a good work ethic which is very much needed right now as I am having to start to prepare for high school.

If your anything like me, you have to have some sort of sound going on in the background. One specific thing I absolutely love about this app is it’s option to put on a sound while the timer is going. These sounds are soothing and don’t distract you. One sound for example, is just the background noise of a rainforest. I use this option all the time when doing homework or even just preparing for an exam. One thing I will have to say about this app is that your forest doesn’t grow very quickly. You have to be constantly using this app to fill up your forest and don’t get many plant options at first. But every time you grow a tree it’s very rewarding to see how your forest grows. Overall, I am so glad I stumbled upon this app and know I will continue to use this in the future. ( If your deciding whether or not to buy this app, I suggest you do. It’s well worth the two dollars. )

developerResponse: {'id': 2338065, 'body': "Hello,\nDue to the fact that Apple doesn't let developers activate apps directly on the phone from the watch, even though we can let users start a planting session on the watch, there will be no difference on the phone; users can still play on it. title: Does not work as advertised
review:
This is not a Pomodoro timer, which is what is advertised. You cannot set short & long break periods or string together Pomodoro sessions.

It is designed to track your time on your phone and set focused lengths of time where you don’t touch your phone. That’s a great idea, but it is not a Pomodoro timer.
developerResponse:
{'id': 4245685, 'body': 'Hi,

Thank you for your feedback.
We would take your suggestions into consideration, and add more techniques of Pomodoro in our future updates.

If you have further questions, feel free to contact us via in-app feedback system. :) - Forest', 'modified': '2018-07-16T07:01:05Z'}

title: iOS discrimination
review: I paid about 2 dollars for this and it doesn’t work. The timer still goes on and the tree still grows as I’m using other apps. The app whitelist setting for some reason doesn’t work for iOS. Fix this!
developerResponse: {'id': 26485348, 'body': "Hi,\nPlease make sure you turn on Deep Focus Mode in the top centre of Forest's main screen to allow Forest to restrict your access to other apps. Unfortunately, as mentioned in the App Store, we cannot detect which app the user is using because of the limitations of the iOS system, and therefore we are unable to implement the App Allow List feature on iOS. As a workaround, we've made Deep Focus Mode, which, when turned off, enables users to use the apps they need while planting. Let us know at support@forestapp.cc if you have any more questions. Have a great day!", 'modified': '2021-11-26T03:36:31Z'}

title: Trying it out now
review:
Might work. I’ll see.

Two important things I see.

First, you can’t use the phone as part of what your focusing on. This is likely okay on a phone, but Forest on the IPad makes no sense at all. I use iPads for working: reading and taking notes among other important activities.

Second, the Forest Watch app doesn’t install. The installation process never completes and restarts from scratch continually.
developerResponse:
{'id': 4639844, 'body': 'Hello,

(1) There is a whitelist feature in the settings, which lets you add apps that you want to use while you are planting.
(2) It is currently not possible to launch apps on the phone with the Apple Watch. If users plant a tree on the Apple Watch, they can still use their phone which violates the main concept of Forest. 

Feel free to contact us via our in-app feedback system if you have further questions or suggestions. :) - Forest', 'modified': '2018-08-14T03:23:38Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 2567311, 'body': "Hello,
Do you mean the coins from the exceeded time? In addition, in our current design, the trees planted under the following conditions won't be counted in the ranking:

1) Using the Work with phone mode and leave the app during planting.
2) Trees planted on multiple devices at the same time will only be counted once
3) If you have planted for more than 1200 mins in the past 24 hours, the trees planted later on won't be counted in the ranking.
4) Each round starts at 00:00 UTC+0 on Monday. Some of your trees may be counted in the previous round because of your time zone. If your case doesn't match any of the above cases, please let us know. Forest", 'modified': '2019-05-13T19:55:23Z'}

developerResponse: {'id': 26520835, 'body': 'Hi there,\r\n\r\nAs mentioned in the App Store, we cannot detect which app the user is using because of the limitation of the iOS system, and therefore we are unable to implement the App Allow List feature in the iOS version. As a workaround, we released the "Deep focus mode" in 2019 which, when disabled, allows users to use other apps while planting. It can be found at the top of the main page. Once you\'ve collected enough coins, unlock new trees in the in-app store or even donate a real tree in the "Real tree" tab! :)', 'modified': '2021-11-29T02:14:02Z'}

title: so good for focusing!
review:
let me just say that this is hands down the BEST app i have ever paid money for.  at first when i bought this app, last year, i wasn’t really in the right mindset to make the most of it.  i didn’t really use it and felt no motivation to use it.  but this year i decided i wanted to be more productive, and not waste time on my phone.  when the new school year started, i had a system: get home from school. eat a snack.  browse social media for 10-15 minutes MAX.  then i’d go to my room and open the forest app, and set it to 25 minutes.  for 25 minutes i do nothing but the task i have in front of me, no distractions, ringer off.  when the 25 minutes are up, i set the break timer to 2-5 minutes, depending on how hard the task was.  during this time i get some water or a snack, stretch, do a mini workout (pull-ups are a quick one), answer any texts, or go outside for some fresh air.  then when my timer is up, i get back to work and do another 25 minutes.  and i keep doing this until i’m about halfway through with all of my work for the day, and i take a 10 minute break to really process the information i took notes on or just take a break.  then i get back to work and repeat the 25 minutes of work, 2-5 minute break cycle.  this system has COMPLETELY changed how i get my work done.  instead of procrastinating and doing it all last minute, or doing 2-3 hours with no breaks, i do a decent amount of work with enough break time in between that i don’t get too exhausted.  one thing if you try to use this method or something similar—while you’re on the break in between work sessions, i recommend NOT going through social media.  answering texts is fine, but i find that for me if i look at social media it’s very hard to go back to work, and i ignore the “get back to work!” notifications.  even if you don’t use this exact system, or something similar, i recommend taking a few breaks because it really does help you understand what you are actually doing.  my grades have gone up a lot after i started using the app for homework, and i have much more free time to do fun things once i’m done with all my homework.  i highly recommend this app to anyone who has work or homework they have to do, and anyone who has a phone and struggles with putting it down and not getting distracted.  i’m sorry this is such a long review, it’s the only review i’ve ever written for anything.  i just felt that people should know how amazing this app is and how it can completely change your life!  also as a bonus when you complete your 25 minutes or whatever time you set, you get credits which you can use to get new types of trees, or if you want you can use them to plant real trees in real life!  

in conclusion. BUY THIS APP :)

title: Good app, helps me focus
review: This is a good app. I have been using it since 2015 and I am pretty satisfied with it. The new tree/bush species are beautiful and having different species really does motivate me to keep planting my garden and to earn more coins so I can unlock a new species. I have huge issues with wasting time on my phone and time management due to executive function issues and mental illness and this app has helped me a lot as a college student. The app can’t force you to do your work, but it CAN force you to take a break from your phone, and that ten minute break can be really, really useful when you are stuck. I also love that you can input custom tags to  track and categorize different categories of planting time (sleeping, class time, homework time, etc) and that you can see your progress on the graph. The options to keep the screen on, track exceeded time, and ding or send a notification when the tree is done are also really helpful for me. My only suggestion would be to show us a better preview of what a tree will look like when planted for a shorter time before we pay coins to unlock it. For example, the preview image for the apple tree shows a big apple tree with apples and a picnic basket, but once you buy the tree you realize that you can’t get it to look that pretty unless you are able to plant it for a longer time, like 40 minutes+. If you are only planting trees for less time, like 30 minutes or less, then a lot of the trees look kind of the same and they are not as colorful or as big as pictured in the store, because they don’t “grow” to look like the picture. Overall I love your app and would absolutely recommend it to anyone who is struggling to break away from their phone. Thank you, Forest app developers! ❤️🌳

developerResponse: {'id': 26485301, 'body': "Hi, \r\n\r\nIn order to create a distraction-free environment, Forest is designed to help users put down their phones and concentrate on their tasks. Users can start a stopwatch or a timer to start a planting session, and choose a tree to plant to their liking. In addition, we've partnered up with Trees for the Future and offer users to plant real trees in the designated countries by being productive! Please make sure you turn on Deep Focus Mode in the top centre of Forest's main screen to allow Forest to restrict your access to other apps. Let us know at support@forestapp.cc if you need any more help!", 'modified': '2021-11-26T03:34:54Z'}

title: So close to perfect!
review:
I’ve used Forest for about a year now, and I love it on my IPhone! Before using Forest, I would find myself using my phone while studying, which would lead me to losing focus and having to reread sections of text because of that lack of focus. When I got this app, however, I started studying much more effectively because the urge to use my phone was no longer there. I would highly recommend this app to anyone who is having difficulty with staying focused!

Now as to ways that Forest can improve the app: I recently bought the Apple Watch SE, and when I saw that forest was available for my watch, I knew I had to download it! When I opened it up, however, I was greatly disappointed. You can’t start a study session on your Watch, and the majority (if not all) of the features that make Forest for the IPhone great aren’t present. To me, it would make sense to add the ability to set a study session on your watch and have the countdown on it. After all, isn’t Forest meant to keep you off your phone? I could over look this, if it weren’t for the fact that you pay for this app. Other apps similar to Forest have the same features on the Watch app and their IPhone app. On top of the superior functionality, some of those apps also have the benefit of being free. 

So to sum up: this app is amazing if you’re using it on your IPhone, but where it can truly shine (in my opinion) is the Apple Watch. Forest is an amazing app, and I truly hope that the developers find a way to add more features to their Apple Watch app.

developerResponse:
{'id': 13118814, 'body': 'Hi,
Sorry for any inconvenience caused, but this is by no means done on purpose. Over 630,000 real trees have been planted by Forest users.
If you still have difficulties signing in to plant real trees, please send us a ticket via the in-app feedback system so that we can assist you further. Thank you! :)
- Forest', 'modified': '2020-01-26T02:09:26Z'}

title: Awesome App!!
review: I have been using the Forest app for almost 2 months now and this app has been amazing!!! It has helped me be way more productive and create so many good habits!! I'm a mom with kids and it's often hard to get motivated to do housework, pay bills, etc., when the same chores stare me in the face day after day. Growing trees gives me just enough incentive to not only get things done but also I can then look back and realize at the end of the day I have actually accomplished something! Also, I have always struggled to maintain good habits such as exercise daily, eat a certain amount of fruits & veggies, get to bed on time, etc., but with this app I grow specific trees/bushes for each habit I maintain each day. I then have a record to not only help me remember to do each habit but to see how long I've maintained it. I know some reviewers mention it's "just a timer" but for me, it's the extra bit I need to motivate me especially as there is a record of my accomplishments. Also, I like that each tree/bush costs an additional 100 coins up to 1000 per tree/bush as early on that motivated me to add more things/habits I grew trees for, which then made it easier/quicker to earn enough coins for the next tree. Just be creative how you use the app!! Finally, and very importantly, I wanted to mention that I had no issues with the app until just the other day when an issue came up with trying to label the trees. I contacted the app makers through feedback under settings and they not only responded but had the bug fixed within 24 hours. For a couple dollars this app is so incredibly worth it!! Thank you!

developerResponse:
{'id': 2451092, 'body': "Could you please check if you have done the following settings:

1) Turn on the notification in the Forest settings page.
2)  Allow Forest to send notification in your phone settings.
3) Turn off the Do Not Disturb Mode.
4) Turn off the Silent Mode or allow the vibration during Silent Mode so that you would still have vibration notification but no sound notification.


If you have done the above tasks but there is still no notification, please feel free to contact us again. We'll examine this problem carefully.

Thank you :) Forest", 'modified': '2018-01-31T02:42:18Z'}

title: App allow list doesn’t work for iOS

developerResponse: {'id': 30206004, 'body': 'Hi,\nAs mentioned in the App Store, we cannot detect which app the user is using because of the limitation of the iOS system, and therefore we are unable to implement the App Allow List feature in the iOS version. As a workaround, we\'ve made the "Deep focus mode" which, when disabled, enables users to use other apps while planting. It can be found at the top of the main page. :)\n- Forest ', 'modified': '2022-06-07T05:21:40Z'}

title: Secret weapon in war against ADD
review: Forest is a vital tool for me in school. I have been using the app for about 11 months now, and I can say it is completely worth the cost. As a college student who has had to work her way back from a 2.0 GPA to a Masters student, I can say that this app has contributed to my growing success academically. I used to get easily side-tracked by notifications on my phone or even just by scrolling through my camera roll to procrastinate. Now, I like logging hours and knowing exactly how much time per day and week I spend preparing for classes. Knowing I can't take a break until my tree is grown keeps my self control strong. Logging study hours gives me confidence before each lecture or test because I can operationally define how much studying is "a lot of studying." Additionally, I use this app as one of several weapons against symptoms of ADD. I used to justify distractions on my phone, telling myself I couldn't miss out when I got a snap chat or Instagram notification. This app has shown me that those social distractions snowballed into hour-long escapades online and kept me from completing basic academic tasks. I tell everyone who asks about this app that it is fantastic. I love that there are new changes, such as the background sounds and 10 second grace periods. Additionally, the opportunities for awards keep me coming back; since the start of fall term I've made it my goal to plant healthy trees thirty days in a row. My suggestion for this app would be to keep it simple no matter how many updates it goes through. Other apps such as Instagram and Snapchat (though they serve entirely different purposes) are receiving poor reviews because they added too many unnecessary features. As someone who gets distracted easily, I fully appreciate the simplicity of this app and its basic reward system. Please keep the app clean and simple! Thank you for this app!

title: Great for Developing Study Habits
review:
Overall, this application is 5/5. The visuals and theme are beautifully done and cohesive throughout all aspects of the application. It is perfect for users seeking to break unhealthy habits so common with cell phone usage. It could be particularly useful to adolescents as their limbic system and prefrontal cortex develop at separate times creating the need to practice and develop executive functioning skills explicitly (Laser, J.A. & Nicotera, N, 2021). Using a rewards system, this application effectively promotes self-discipline and self-regulation. The positive reward of growing a successful tree or forest capitalizes on adolescents heightened sensitivity and desire for reward (Steinberg 2014). Instead of creating a punishment or negative consequence for the inability to stay focused and off other apps, Forest rewards time well spent. Users can choose what type of trees they want to plan and work towards earning coins to buy a bigger selection of trees and plants. This allows the user to really make their forest their own and become invested in it, therefore helping positive brain development.  

A huge benefit is the ability to train the user’s brain to focus for extended periods of time. By starting at ten minutes and with the ability to go to 120 minutes, the user can increase at their own pace the amount of time they can enter focus mode. Through varied rewards, the application encourages the practice and growth of self-discipline. The achievement badges for users who plant trees multiple days in a row and establish practice patterns really emphasize the importance of practice and repetition for positive brain development and self-regulation. The more the user practices self-regulation and self-control through the app, the easier it will become.

title: Growing with Forest: Technology and Procrastination
review: In a residential university setting, there are already so many distractions that I face. Most of my friends live just down the hall, social events occur every night, and activities in my dorm and clubs have become a part of my daily life. When I am finally able to escape this frenzy of socialization and sit down in the library, I confront the most tempting distraction of them all: my smartphone. I grew up in a generation of social media and personal technology, and in result, I have become somewhat dependent on the constant stream of information and entertainment available to me on my mobile device. From Twitter to Snapchat to Instagram, there are endless feeds to go through, videos to watch, and people to talk to. In the past, I have taken extreme measures in attempt to squelch my temptations toward the infinite scroll. I have turned off my phone, deleted applications, and logged out of accounts. Despite my efforts, I have always failed to honor my own restrictions, regardless of the fact that it is in my best interests. Because I had not found a solution to my tendency towards distraction, I decided to try ‘Forest,’ a focus-motivating iOS application for smartphones. Forest uses the symbol of a tree in order to motivate users to stop their phone use. When one uses Forest, one sets a timer on the app, and throughout the duration of the set time, a virtual tree grows. If one uses one’s phone as a timer is ongoing, the tree dies. In using Forest as a part of my student workflow, I found that its usability, aesthetic design, and conceptual design work well into my practice of study. Although I observed that the app helps me focus in times of high-intensity study, I will probably not use it in the future for relatively low-urgency schoolwork.

developerResponse:
{'id': 4299762, 'body': 'Hello,

Due to the limitation of the iOS system, we cannot determine what app the user is currently using. Therefore we cannot implement the whitelist feature for the iOS version. As a workaround, we built a "Work with Phone" feature, which can be enabled in the settings page. This feature enables users to use work related apps during their planting periods, but users will have to be honest with themselves when using this feature. 

The trees planted with this feature enabled will not be counted towards the leaderboard, and users will only receive half the reward if they exit Forest during the planting period. 

Currently, the whitelist feature cannot be implemented for iOS. If you see features similar to whitelist on other apps, please let us know so that we may figure out how it was implemented. 

Thank you for your suggestion. :)', 'modified': '2019-04-23T22:26:03Z'}

developerResponse: {'id': 21764866, 'body': 'Hi, thank you for the feedback. You don\'t actually have to pay money for the trees, you can earn the coins by focusing more. The main purpose of this app is to help users stay focused on their tasks and the coin mechanism is there to motivate users to stay focused more and unlock the trees that they like. If you would like to make the trees grow faster, there are also options such as "Sunshine Elixir" for you to purchase. You can completely decide whether you want to purchase or not on your own. Please let us know if you have any other questions. :)\n', 'modified': '2021-03-20T03:23:51Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 18403495, 'body': 'Hi,
Bushes are planted under 20 minutes, and trees are planted over 25 minutes. Set your time accordingly to which plant you want by dragging the dot that surrounds the circle on the main planting page.

You can switch tree species by tapping on the tree image inside the circle on the home page. Tap "Plant" to start a planting session. Once it's finished, you will gain coins which allow you to unlock more tree species; you can also earn coins by unlocking achievements. The trees you've planted will stay in your Forest.

Hope this helps! You are very welcomed to ask us if you have any more questions. You can also refer to the FAQ page which offers many tips for new users. Thank you! :)', 'modified': '2020-10-11T11:38:00Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 27242807, 'body': 'Hi, do you have a passcode for your device? Due to iOS system limitations, a passcode is required for Deep Focus Mode to work.
﻿
﻿Note that the mode can only be toggled on or off before a planting session. The switch will stay fixed once a tree starts.
﻿
﻿Please try again and if the issue persists, contact us via the in-app feedback system with a screenshot of the problem. Thank you and sorry for any inconvenience caused. Feel free to reach out to us again if you have any more concerns!', 'modified': '2022-01-05T01:52:09Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 6779256, 'body': 'Hello,

Due to the limitation of the iOS system, we cannot determine what app the user is currently using. Therefore we cannot implement the whitelist feature for the iOS version. As a workaround, we built a "Work with Phone" feature, which can be enabled in the settings page. This feature enables users to use work related apps during their planting periods, but users will have to be honest with themselves when using this feature. 

The trees planted with this feature enabled will not be counted towards the leaderboard, and users will only receive half the reward if they exit Forest during the planting period. 

Currently, the whitelist feature cannot be implemented for iOS. If you see features similar to whitelist on other apps, please let us know so that we may figure out how it was implemented. 

Thank you for your suggestion. :) - Forest', 'modified': '2019-05-27T23:23:32Z'}

title: Improved my career/grad school habits…and
review: The 1st and only app that has effectively changed my life for the better. The support/accountability of being in the Discord/Facebook communities is great for planting trees that I don’t have (but that the room owner has), so I can focus on saving for planting Real Trees. But this review wouldn’t be helpful to the developers if I didn’t mention some possible improvements that would make it 5 stars: #1. The daily ranking for “Deep Focus” time has been counting the time when I disable “Deep Focus” mode too. Either the rankings should just say “Focus Mode Rankings”, or the rankings should only include time when “Deep Focus” is enabled. I recommend the latter option because I planted with “Deep Focus” disabled, then I closed the app, and scrolled through Instagram for over an hour, and still got coins/trees. I tested it again to make sure: I planted a tree, then I exited the forest app (closed it completely), opened up Instagram, waited for a minute, and when I reopened the forest app, the tree was still growing and the remaining time hadn’t even stopped counting down while the app was closed. It defeats the entire purpose of the app/rankings. #2. Add room invitations to the timeline. This would be so valuable. I’ve accidentally dismissed room invitations, and I know people sometimes wait 10+ minutes before starting to grow the plant so that people can find the link and join the room, but I can’t view my “recent invitations” or anything to join the room if I accidentally dismissed it. When that happens, it feels like I’ve really missed out, and I get discouraged. But if the invitation were in the timeline or even in a “Recent Invitations” section for 30 minutes, and it included a link to the room, I would almost definitely be able to join more foresters for growing sessions. #3. Add an optional “status” field to my profile for friends (or specific friends) to see. Also, the option to make the “tag” visible to friends would be great too. That way, my real life friends can check why I’m not responding to texts by checking my Forest status and would see that my planting status is “active” and the tag says “meditation”, so they know that I’m not just ignoring them. The option to make these things visible to friends would be a nice addition. #4 I would love it if my screen could rotate while the plant is growing. You allow the screen to stay on so I can see the plant grow periodically, but I like to lean my phone up against something so I can glance at it now and then…If my phone is charging, then it must be sideways for it to be leaned up against something (or else it will need to balance on the charger cable and that causes it to fall and become a distraction). If it rotated, then I could have it on it’s side, but still see the plant grow in the right direction because the screen orientation would have adapted to landscape. I’m only speaking from my experience, so I understand if these ideas don’t make it to production, but I think there are good reasons for them. Thanks for reading !
